title: Are we in Plato's cave? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, because the allegory of the cave was meant to convey the idea that what we observe is not real reality but rather a shadow of the Forms. I reject the Forms as being actual reality because what we observe is real reality — what you see is what you get, in terms of the fundamentals. In other words, reality is really composed of entities that have attributes and can engage in motions or changes. Plato was against change or at least fell for the ancient belief that if it changes then it cannot be perfection, because to be perfect meant that a thing would not change over time because this would take it away from a perfect state of being. Also, Plato did not understand causation and therefore thought it was an illusion of the senses. But Aristotle corrected that particular mistaken view by coming up with his four causes to explain motion or change. Here is what Ayn Rand thought of change or motion: “To grasp the axiom that existence exists, means to grasp the fact that nature, i.e., the universe as a whole, cannot be created or annihilated, that it cannot come into or go out of existence. Whether its basic constituent elements are atoms, or subatomic particles, or some yet undiscovered forms of energy, it is not ruled by a consciousness or by will or by chance, but by the law of identity. All the countless forms, motions, combinations and dissolutions of elements within the universe—from a floating speck of dust to the formation of a galaxy to the emergence of life—are caused and determined by the identities of the elements involved.” -Ayn Rand Lexicon I also wrote an essay on causation that I think is accurate and a further example from Ayn Rand’s understanding of causation: “Some people seem to think that one has to get to the particular aspect of the entity that leads to the conclusion that it acts that way under those circumstance due to that particular factual nature of the entity. An example would be that water boils at that temperature due to the hydrogen bonds breaking which transforms water (a liquid) into water vapor (a gas). But while this is true, it is an advanced scientific – special science’s – understanding of why water boils, and comes only after one understands that water boils due to the fact that it is water. One has to grasp that an entity acts the way it does due to that fact that it is what it is, before one can abstract further and get to the more specific cause of that particular action, and the philosophical knowledge that an entity acts due to what it is precedes the scientific knowledge. What I’m claiming is that one observes that it is water directly and observes that it boils directly, and that the boiling (action) is abstracted from the water (entity), leading to cause and effect – water is the cause (a fact about water) leads it to act that way (boiling) under those conditions (sufficient heat).” Causality Given in Observation

Let us begin by taking the allegory to mean that there is a real world whose nature is independent of appearance, and, that as we commonly know from illusion, there is no a priori guarantee that appearance is what is real or that appearance precisely reveals the real. Of course, we know (e.g., from Descartes’ Cogito argument) that there are appearances. So that is one mark against the idea that we are irrevocably in the cave. On the other hand, it does indeed seem that we may never be able to entirely transcend appearance and arrive at final, complete, and true knowledge of the real. Let us examine that. I think it is fair to argue that some appearances reveal the real in some rough sense to some degree of approximation. Notice that I said ‘reveal’ and not ‘correspond to’ (or something along the lines of a theory of truth). That is, I am being vague about what truth is (at this point). However, I am able to negotiate the world as it appears with some degree of success and I think it would be too much to argue that all of the apparent success is merely apparent—i.e. is illusory. So, then, appearance has some efficacy as a measure of the real. To say that is not to say we are out of the cave but it is saying that what is going on in the cave partakes of the real even if it is not precisely the real. What is more, if it is argued that we can never get out of appearance entirely, then surely we have two options (i) admit we can never have perfect knowledge according to a realist (not pragmatic) theory of truth or (ii) say that realist theories of truth do not make entire sense to maintain. A problem, though, is that we do not know whether we can get entirely beyond appearances. But we can do so sometimes. We already saw that there are appearances and that they are part of the world. We can also say “If being is what there is, then there is being.” We can say “If we define the universe as all being, then there is a universe.” We can then also say “If material cause is interaction among different beings then, since there is no other being for the universe, there is no effective cause on the universe.” We can also say “If a creator is another being, the universe has no creator.” That is we can arrive at perfect knowledge. Some perfect knowledge, that is. But note that the perfection arrived at is the result of abstracting out from the world only its features so general that they are not subject to the distorting effect of illusion. Conclusion—of course, with some hesitation: From a truth perspective we will always have one foot in the cave and one out in the light. We can arrive at some truth; but we can never overcome illusion (or incompleteness of knowledge) entirely.But if that is true, then it makes perfect truth in all things undesirable—for it makes no sense to desire the impossible.We therefore (as has been argued) prefer to not disengage our theory of knowledge from our theory of value and think that our imperfection from one perspective is perfection from another. That is, while we ought not to stop striving to become better (e.g. have better knowledge) we ought not to think that we are lesser being because we have not yet arrived.

response.answer_text: Are we in Plato's cave? Yes. Insofar as our minds are concerned with anxiety, anger, jealousy, fear, or negativity of any kind — and not with uplifting, noble and inspiring positive thoughts — we are in the Plato’s cave. The cave allegory can be understood in two senses: cognitively, and in a religious/spiritual way. At the cognitive level, it symbolizes how we are chained to false opinions. We develop and cling to false opinions because unregulated appetites and desires distort our thinking. At a spiritual level, being in the cave symbolizes a mental life oriented towards material things. Plato argues that both to think clearly and to live happily our thinking should be guided by eternal verities of Truth, Beauty and Harmony, and by our highest innate sense of the Good. The solution Plato proposes is a renovation of the mind by moral development (especially the virtues of Courage, Moderation, Prudence, Righteousness and Holiness), and by focused sharpening of the intellect (dialectic).

response.answer_text: I don't believe this question has certain and obvious answers. The very fundamental reason of staying in a cave is not knowing you are in a cave. It is however most likely to be in multiple caves that contains inner caves and conjunctions of caves. Your biology is a cave. Your nationality and your culture is a cave. Your family structure, your states values, your relatives, your friends are all caves as well. Some have deeper walls and higher hierarchy. So yes, you are in a cave most certainly I'd say. It is however fairy illogical and ineffective to observe your walls without being inside a cave I believe. And yet one can argue against being inside a cave and believing existence of a cave is actually willingly accepting residing in a cave. One of the most astonishing realizations of being in a cave is you obtain certain amount of self-doubt and scepticism that you should use always.

Original Question: Are we in Plato’s cave? Most of us, yes. I know I am. :-) But a gifted minority are halfway out, thanks to mathematics. In an age when our favorite tech is made possible in part by higher mathematics, we can’t deny how much math enhances human perception and understanding of the world. Absent mathematics, humans would not understand nearly so much—we’d be all the way into the cave. Plato believed that abstract qualitative information, usually translated as “The Forms,” could further enhance our perception and understanding of the world. Having mastered comprehension of the Forms, one would be all the way out of the cave, so to speak.

response.answer_text: Of course we are. Our teachers stand behind us holding smooth figures that cast shadows on the wall. With them are our religious leaders and politicians. When we meet expectations, the reward us with degrees. Some of us get as far as turning our heads toward the light, but only Socrates can fully ascend into the presence of Forms. Only he, prompted by his daimon, has ultimate authority in his imaginary universe.

I would say yes, in the sense the cave represents our superficial physical reality. Our senses only allow us to perceive a small fraction of what exists and takes place around us. We can therefore only define a very limited reality which falls far short of totality. The chains in Plato’s allegory represent the bondage of our limited senses and thus ignorance. The shadows on the walls represent the superficial truth of our limited perceptions. The freed prisoner represents an understanding that the physical world is only a shadow of truth. The glaring sun in the eyes of the prisoners represents an ideal higher truth. It also represents wisdom.

Most, yes. To believe that we are the physical body instead of eternal spirit souls is an illusion, like the shadows in Plato’s cave. But, the moment we realized we are spirit souls distinct from our bodies, be become free from the chains of illusion that binds us. We see ourselves and others as their real selves inside their bodies, including plants and animals. The greatest freedom is realizing we are eternal children of God and the goal and meaning of life is to reestablish Sanatan Dharma - our eternal duty/function in connection with loving God. This is removing our shackles and finally getting out of the dark cave of illusion.

response.answer_text: We are, if our worldview is WYSIATI, and we are not fully aware of it. The cave allegory is an ancient formulation of the confirmation bias like Francis Bacon's four idols of the mind. Escaping the cave requires slow thinking and quick feet, otherwise it's impossible to ponder the metaphysical problem of Plato's philosophy.

I think it’s arrogant to assume one has been emancipated from the cave. Each of us can be critical thinkers in one area, but following a herd or living according to emotion and passion in another field. Someone might be aware of environmental degradation, but due to economic nescience they could give a lousy suggestion on how to combat it because of a herd mentality within their ilk. I think everyone has one foot in the cave.
